segment.source: Connection group file purpose and location
segment.target: Connection group file purpose and location

segment.source: Connection group purpose
segment.target: Connection group purpose

segment.source: A connection group is an App-V feature that enables you to group packages together to create a virtual environment in which the applications in those packages can interact with each other.
segment.target: A connection group is an App-V feature that enables you to group packages together to create a virtual environment in which the applications in those packages can interact with each other.

segment.source: Example: You want to use plug-ins with Microsoft Office.
segment.target: Example: You want to use plug-ins with Microsoft Office.

segment.source: You can create a package that contains the plug-ins, and create another package that contains Office, and then add both packages to a connection group to enable Office to use those plug-ins.
segment.target: You can create a package that contains the plug-ins, and create another package that contains Office, and then add both packages to a connection group to enable Office to use those plug-ins.

segment.source: How the connection group file works
segment.target: How the connection group file works

segment.source: When you apply an Application Virtualization 5.0 connection group file, the packages that are enumerated in the file will be combined at runtime into a single virtual environment.
segment.target: When you apply an Application Virtualization 5.0 connection group file, the packages that are enumerated in the file will be combined at runtime into a single virtual environment.

segment.source: Use the Microsoft Application Virtualization (App-V) 5.0 connection group file to configure existing Application Virtualization 5.0 connection groups.
segment.target: Use the Microsoft Application Virtualization (App-V) 5.0 connection group file to configure existing Application Virtualization 5.0 connection groups.

segment.source: Example file path
segment.target: Example file path

segment.source: %APPDATA%\Microsoft\AppV\Client\Catalog\PackageGroups6CCC7575-162E-4152-9407-ED411DA138F4}4D1E16E1-8EF8-41ED-92D5-8910A8527F96}.
segment.target: %APPDATA%\Microsoft\AppV\Client\Catalog\PackageGroups6CCC7575-162E-4152-9407-ED411DA138F4}4D1E16E1-8EF8-41ED-92D5-8910A8527F96}.

segment.source: Parameters that define the connection group
segment.target: Parameters that define the connection group

segment.source: The following table describes the parameters in the XML file that define the connection group itself, not the packages.
segment.target: The following table describes the parameters in the XML file that define the connection group itself, not the packages.

segment.source: Field
segment.target: Field

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Schema name
segment.target: Schema name

segment.source: Name of the schema.
segment.target: Name of the schema.

segment.source: Applicable starting in App-V 5.0 SP3: If you want to use the new “optional packages” and “use any version” features that are described in this table, you must specify the following schema in the XML file:
segment.target: Applicable starting in App-V 5.0 SP3: If you want to use the new “optional packages” and “use any version” features that are described in this table, you must specify the following schema in the XML file:

segment.source: AppConnectionGroupId
segment.target: AppConnectionGroupId

segment.source: Unique GUID identifier for this connection group.
segment.target: Unique GUID identifier for this connection group.

segment.source: The connection group state is associated with this identifier.
segment.target: The connection group state is associated with this identifier.

segment.source: Specify this identifier only when you create the connection group.
segment.target: Specify this identifier only when you create the connection group.

segment.source: You can create a new GUID by typing: .
segment.target: You can create a new GUID by typing: .

segment.source: VersionId
segment.target: VersionId

segment.source: Version GUID identifier for this version of the connection group.
segment.target: Version GUID identifier for this version of the connection group.

segment.source: When you update a connection group (for example, by adding or updating a new package), you must update the version GUID to reflect the new version.
segment.target: When you update a connection group (for example, by adding or updating a new package), you must update the version GUID to reflect the new version.

segment.source: DisplayName
segment.target: DisplayName

segment.source: Display name of the connection group.
segment.target: Display name of the connection group.

segment.source: Priority
segment.target: Priority

segment.source: Optional priority field for the connection group.
segment.target: Optional priority field for the connection group.

segment.source: “0” indicates the highest priority.
segment.target: “0” indicates the highest priority.

segment.source: If a priority is required, but has not been configured, the package will fail because the correct connection group to use cannot be determined.
segment.target: If a priority is required, but has not been configured, the package will fail because the correct connection group to use cannot be determined.

segment.source: Parameters that define the packages in the connection group
segment.target: Parameters that define the packages in the connection group

segment.source: In the Packages section of the connection group XML file, you list the member packages in the connection group by specifying each package’s unique package identifier and version identifier, as described in the following table.
segment.target: In the Packages section of the connection group XML file, you list the member packages in the connection group by specifying each package’s unique package identifier and version identifier, as described in the following table.

segment.source: The first package in the list has the highest precedence.
segment.target: The first package in the list has the highest precedence.

segment.source: Field
segment.target: Field

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: PackageId
segment.target: PackageId

segment.source: Unique GUID identifier for this package.
segment.target: Unique GUID identifier for this package.

segment.source: This GUID doesn’t change when newer versions of the package are published.
segment.target: This GUID doesn’t change when newer versions of the package are published.

segment.source: VersionId
segment.target: VersionId

segment.source: Unique GUID identifier for the version of the package.
segment.target: Unique GUID identifier for the version of the package.

segment.source: Applicable starting in App-V 5.0 SP3: If you specify “*” for the package version, the GUID of the latest available package version is dynamically inserted.
segment.target: Applicable starting in App-V 5.0 SP3: If you specify “*” for the package version, the GUID of the latest available package version is dynamically inserted.

segment.source: IsOptional
segment.target: IsOptional

segment.source: Applicable starting in App-V 5.0 SP3: Parameter that enables you to make a package optional within the connection group.
segment.target: Applicable starting in App-V 5.0 SP3: Parameter that enables you to make a package optional within the connection group.

segment.source: Valid entries are:
segment.target: Valid entries are:

segment.source: “true” – package is optional in the connection group
segment.target: “true” – package is optional in the connection group

segment.source: “false” – package is required in the connection group
segment.target: “false” – package is required in the connection group

segment.source: See How to Use Optional Packages in Connection Groups.
segment.target: See How to Use Optional Packages in Connection Groups.

segment.target: App-V 5.0 SP3 example connection group XML file

segment.source: Configuring the priority of packages in a connection group
segment.target: Configuring the priority of packages in a connection group

segment.source: Package precedence is configured using the package list order.
segment.target: Package precedence is configured using the package list order.

segment.source: The first package in the document has the highest precedence.
segment.target: The first package in the document has the highest precedence.

segment.source: Subsequent packages in the list have descending priority.
segment.target: Subsequent packages in the list have descending priority.

segment.source: Package precedence is the resolution for otherwise inevitable resource collisions during virtual environment initialization.
segment.target: Package precedence is the resolution for otherwise inevitable resource collisions during virtual environment initialization.

segment.source: For example, if two packages that are opening in the same virtual environment define the same registry DWORD value, the package with the highest precedence determines the value that is set.
segment.target: For example, if two packages that are opening in the same virtual environment define the same registry DWORD value, the package with the highest precedence determines the value that is set.

segment.source: You can use the connection group file to configure each connection group by using the following methods:
segment.target: You can use the connection group file to configure each connection group by using the following methods:

segment.source: Specify runtime priorities for connection groups.
segment.target: Specify runtime priorities for connection groups.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Priority is required only if the package is associated with more than one connection group.
segment.target: Priority is required only if the package is associated with more than one connection group.

segment.source: Specify package precedence within the connection group.
segment.target: Specify package precedence within the connection group.

segment.source: The priority field is required when a running virtual application initiates from a native application request, for example, Microsoft Windows Explorer.
segment.target: The priority field is required when a running virtual application initiates from a native application request, for example, Microsoft Windows Explorer.

segment.source: The App-V client uses the priority to determine which connection group virtual environment the application should run in.
segment.target: The App-V client uses the priority to determine which connection group virtual environment the application should run in.

segment.source: This situation occurs if a virtual application is part of multiple connection groups.
segment.target: This situation occurs if a virtual application is part of multiple connection groups.

segment.source: If a virtual application is opened using another virtual application the virtual environment of the original virtual application will be used.
segment.target: If a virtual application is opened using another virtual application the virtual environment of the original virtual application will be used.

segment.source: The priority field is not used in this case.
segment.target: The priority field is not used in this case.

segment.source: Example:
segment.target: Example:

segment.source: The virtual application Microsoft Outlook is running in virtual environment XYZ.
segment.target: The virtual application Microsoft Outlook is running in virtual environment XYZ.

segment.source: When you open an attached Microsoft Word document, a virtualized version Microsoft Word opens in the virtual environment XYZ, regardless of the virtualized Microsoft Word’s associated connection groups or runtime priorities.
segment.target: When you open an attached Microsoft Word document, a virtualized version Microsoft Word opens in the virtual environment XYZ, regardless of the virtualized Microsoft Word’s associated connection groups or runtime priorities.

segment.source: An.
segment.target: An.

segment.source: exe file and plug-in (.dll)
segment.target: exe file and plug-in (.dll)

segment.source: You want to distribute Microsoft Office to all users, but distribute a Microsoft Excel plug-in to only a subset of users.
segment.target: You want to distribute Microsoft Office to all users, but distribute a Microsoft Excel plug-in to only a subset of users.

segment.source: Enable the connection group for the appropriate users.
segment.target: Enable the connection group for the appropriate users.

segment.source: Update each package individually as required.
segment.target: Update each package individually as required.

segment.source: An.
segment.target: An.

segment.source: exe file and a middleware application
segment.target: exe file and a middleware application

segment.source: You have an application requires a middleware application, or several applications that all depend on the same middleware runtime version.
segment.target: You have an application requires a middleware application, or several applications that all depend on the same middleware runtime version.

segment.source: All computers that require one or more of the applications receive the connection groups with the application and middleware application runtime.
segment.target: All computers that require one or more of the applications receive the connection groups with the application and middleware application runtime.

segment.source: You can optionally combine multiple middleware applications into a single connection group.
segment.target: You can optionally combine multiple middleware applications into a single connection group.

segment.target: Example

segment.source: An.
segment.target: An.

segment.source: exe file and an .exe file
segment.target: exe file and an .exe file

segment.source: You have an application that relies on another application, and you want to keep the packages separate for operational efficiencies, licensing restrictions, or rollout timelines.
segment.target: You have an application that relies on another application, and you want to keep the packages separate for operational efficiencies, licensing restrictions, or rollout timelines.

segment.source: Example:
segment.target: Example:

segment.source: If you are deploying Microsoft Lync 2010, you can use three packages:
segment.target: If you are deploying Microsoft Lync 2010, you can use three packages:

segment.source: Microsoft Office 2010
segment.target: Microsoft Office 2010

segment.source: Microsoft Communicator 2007
segment.target: Microsoft Communicator 2007

segment.source: Microsoft Lync 2010
segment.target: Microsoft Lync 2010

segment.source: You can manage the deployment using the following connection groups:
segment.target: You can manage the deployment using the following connection groups:

segment.source: Microsoft Office 2010 and Microsoft Communicator 2007
segment.target: Microsoft Office 2010 and Microsoft Communicator 2007

segment.source: Microsoft Office 2010 and Microsoft Lync 2010
segment.target: Microsoft Office 2010 and Microsoft Lync 2010

segment.source: When the deployment has completed, you can either create a single new Microsoft Office 2010 + Microsoft Lync 2010 package, or keep and maintain them as separate packages and deploy them by using a connection group.
segment.target: When the deployment has completed, you can either create a single new Microsoft Office 2010 + Microsoft Lync 2010 package, or keep and maintain them as separate packages and deploy them by using a connection group.
